thread.title: Lady Indians regain top form, repeat as 3- champs
thread.title_full: Lady Indians regain top form, repeat as 3- champs

title: Lady Indians regain top form, repeat as 3- champs
text:
Comments 
Senior Dominique Ingram goes for a kill against Newnan’s front line. 
When East Coweta’s volleyball team took the court Saturday at home in the Area 3- Tournament, it had only one thing on its mind. 
Revenge. 
The No. 2 seeded Lady Indians got their wish, beating rival and top-seeded Newnan twice, including a sweep in the best-of-five championship round (25-23, 25-22 and 25-18). 
Earlier in the day, East Coweta beat Newnan in a winner’s bracket contest (25- 20, 21-25, 25-21) to send the Lady Cougars into a contest with Campbell. 
Newnan regrouped against the Lady Spartans (25-20, 25-17) to move to the championship and set up its rematch with East Coweta in the finals. 
The Lady Cougars entered the tournament after going unbeaten during the regular season area schedule, including a win over East Coweta in the Coweta County Championship. 
By winning the region title, East Coweta defends last year’s area crown and opens to the first round of the Class state tournament as the No. 1 seed. 
“I think we are more confident team than when we lost to them before,” East Coweta head coach Amber McClure said. “I have said since the beginning of the season, it is going to take time. We have two freshmen and three sophomores starting, so we just had to grow into it, and that is what the difference is right now.” 
For its effort this season, Newnan — in its first season under head coach Krista Wilson — still will get the opportunity to host a Class first-round playoff match as the No. 2 seed from 3- . Campbell and Douglas County finished third and fourth, respectively. 
“I am disappointed we did not win against our biggest rivals,” Wilson said. “I think they were just really ready for us. It’s been a good year and we are excited about going to state. I thought everybody played hard for us.” 
East Coweta seniors Sydney Winters, Peyton Smith and Dominique Ingram led the team in the title match. Winters led the Lady Indians with 14 digs and 17 kills, while middle hitter Dominique Ingram had 16 kills. At setter, Smith led with 44 assists to go with 10 digs. 
Junior libero Riley Padgett led the defensive effort with 33 digs. 
“I think we played with more emotion this time,” Ingram said. 
Freshmen Becca Sieckmann and Isabel Moller chimed in with 10 and 7 digs, respectively. Sophomore Allie Edwards added three blocks. 
“We have some young players on this team, but I think we are getting better every day,” Smith said. 
Newnan took control of the first set in the championship round between the two schools jumping out to a 19-12 lead, but East Coweta rallied, outscoring the Lady Cougars 13-4 down the stretch. 
The Lady Indians momentum carried over to the second set, building a 17-8 lead at one stretch before Newnan fought back to cut it 23-21. 
But the Lady Indians were able to take the 2-0 lead after Padgett and Winters scored points down the stretch. 
Newnan senior Jenni Young helped put away several points, and Hailey Goolsby and Olivia Masonheimer helped keep points alive during the late scoring spurt. Libero Hallie Goolsby led the defensive effort while Callie Bass and Ansley Knight each had multiple blocks in the loss. 
The Lady Indians jumped out early in the third set leading 14-7. 
Like it did in the second set, Newnan made another run, cutting East Coweta’s lead to 16-15 only to have the Lady Indians close out the sweep with a 9-3 run. More
